;;一名供应商在洛杉矶的大麻市场上袋装裸盖菇素蘑菇。
;

;加利福尼亚州将不得不州长加文·纽瑟姆 (Gavin Newsom) 周六在一份声明中表示，在州长加文·纽瑟姆 (Gavin Newsom) 签署一项法案之前，将加大力度将致幻剂合法化，并宣布该法案已被否决。

;

;这项被否决的法律预计将于 2019 年生效。到 2025 年，将废除对个人拥有天然致幻剂的人的刑事处罚。它还要求该州成立一个小组来研究这些药物的治疗用途并提出建议。

;

;2016 年支持大麻合法化的民主党人纽瑟姆在周六的一份声明中表示，还需要采取更多措施在加利福尼亚州将致幻剂合法化之前完成。

;

;“加利福尼亚州应立即开始制定受监管的治疗指南，其中包括剂量信息、治疗指南、指导治疗期间防止滥用的规则以及对致幻剂的医疗许可。没有潜在的精神病，”纽瑟姆的声明说。 “不幸的是，这项法案将在这些指导方针实施之前将持有合法化，我无法签署它。”

;

;这项立法呼应了俄勒冈州和科罗拉多州的类似措施，是在毒品改革多年努力之后出台的倡导者和州立法者。代表旧金山的州参议员斯科特·维纳 (Scott Wiener) 于 2022 年底提出了该法案，他认为这是消除“毒品战争”危害并开辟心理健康治疗新途径的重要途径。

; < “退伍军人和任何患有创伤后应激障碍和抑郁症的人不应因寻求救济而面临刑事处罚，”维纳在立法机构通过这项措施后发表声明说。 “植物性迷幻药不会上瘾，并且在治疗我们国家心理健康危机的一些最棘手的驱动因素方面显示出巨大的前景。”

;
;

;;相关：;;大想法：医生应该能够开迷幻药？;

;
;

;维纳支持了 2021 年立法机构的一项努力，但该法案也未能取得进展。维纳说，今年的法案是在与执法团体和医学专家协商后制定的，并采取了“温和的方法”。

;

;提倡创伤替代疗法的退伍军人团体对这项立法表示赞赏。

; < p>;“刑事处罚阻止退伍军人获取迷幻植物药物的每一天，他们的生命就面临着危险，”退伍军人兼英雄之心项目创始人杰西·古尔德在维纳办公室分享的一份声明中表示。

;

;“在传统医学多年来对我不起作用之后，迷幻药帮助我治愈了我在反恐战争中服役时看不见的伤疤。从那时起，我一生致力于教育退伍军人如何安全有效地使用致幻剂。取消对使用这些物质的刑事处罚将有助于这项工作，而不是损害它。”

;

;维纳称否决权让加州错失了遵循科学和领导国家的机会。

;

; >;“这对大量加州人来说是一个挫折，包括退伍军人和急救人员，他们安全地使用这些非成瘾物质并从中受益，但根据加州法律，他们现在将继续被归类为犯罪分子，”维纳在《加州法律》中说道。周六发表声明。 “毫无争议的证据表明，将获取这些物质定为刑事犯罪只会降低人们的安全性并减少获得帮助的机会。”

;

;他表示他将在未来推出新的立法。维纳去年试图通过一项更广泛的立法，该立法也将使用和拥有 LSD 和 MDMA（俗称摇头丸）合法化。

;

;立法者可以以三分之二的票数推翻州长的否决。 ，但他们几十年来都没有尝试过。

;

;;三名共和党人;与民主党人一起支持该法案，为该法案提供了在议会通过所需的票数，并进入州参议院，并在州参议院获得批准。其中一位立法者 Bil​​l Essayli 表示，他最初反对该法案，但因年龄要求和个人使用限制而动摇。

;

;Essayli 告诉 ;法院新闻;如果迷幻药可以帮助那些与心理健康作斗争的人，他们应该能够获得这些药物。

;

;“我们在医学界处理心理健康问题的方法并不奏效，”他说。

;

;在俄勒冈州，2020 年的选民选择将小额交易合法化硬性毒品以及裸盖菇素的监督使用。该州是第一个向公众提供迷幻蘑菇受控使用的州，数千人正在寻求治疗。支持者希望这一举措将彻底改变精神卫生保健。

;

;在加利福尼亚州，奥克兰、旧金山、圣克鲁斯和伯克利等城市已将来自植物和真菌的天然致幻剂合法化。

;

;尽管如此纽瑟姆否决后，加州选民明年可能有机会参与这个问题。支持者正试图在 2024 年 11 月的投票中提出两项扩大迷幻剂使用的倡议。其中一项将使 21 岁及以上人群使用和销售蘑菇合法化，另一项则要求选民批准借款 50 亿美元，建立一个负责研究迷幻疗法的国家机构。

;

;内森·霍华德 (Nathan Howard)，该机构的主任培训裸盖菇素促进剂的 InnerTrek 运营部门表示，俄勒冈州的实验取得了成功，该州的进展可能帮助加州的法案获得了推动力。

;

;“这确实有效。这不仅对我们俄勒冈州以及所有有时会获得救生经历的人来说很重要，而且也非常重要，因为人们正在密切关注这一点。”

;

;在加利福尼亚州，包括奥克兰、旧金山、圣克鲁斯在内的城市和伯克利已经将来自植物和真菌的天然致幻剂合法化。

;

;随着这家意大利时装屋宣布与 Axiom Space 建立最新合作伙伴关系，Prada 将把其设计提升到一个新的大气水平为宇航员设计宇航服。

;

;本周，这家总部位于米兰的奢侈品牌宣布与这家总部位于德克萨斯州的商业航天公司合作，为其 2025 年阿耳忒弥斯 III 任务（首次载人飞行）设计美国宇航局的月球太空服。自 1972 年阿波罗 17 号以来，Prada 的工程师将在整个设计过程中与 Axiom Space 系统团队合作，并开发材料和设计功能的解决方案，以保护宇航员免受来自太空和太空的各种挑战。月球环境，两家公司在一份联合新闻稿中宣布;声明;。

;

;“我们Axiom Space 首席执行官 Michael Suffredini 表示：“我们很高兴与 Prada 合作开发 Axiom 舱外移动装置 (AxEMU) 宇航服。”

;

;“Prada 在原材料、制造技术和创新设计理念方面的技术专长将带来先进技术他补充道：“这不仅有助于确保宇航员在月球表面的舒适度，而且还有助于考虑传统宇航服中所缺乏的急需的人为因素。”

;

;

;“不断发展美国宇航局的舱外探索声明称，Axiom Space 宇航服的设计目的是提供更高的灵活性、更好的保护以抵御恶劣的环境，以及用于探索和科学机会的专用工具。

;

;Artemis III这将是美国宇航局首次前往月球南极的载人任务，其中包括第一位登陆月球的女性和第一位有色人种。据美国宇航局称，宇航员将拍摄月球表面的照片和视频，调查地质情况，并从月球南极取回各种样本。

;

;“阿耳忒弥斯三号宇航员收集的信息和材料将增加我们对月球南极的了解。”神秘的南极地区、月球和我们的太阳系，”;说;美国宇航局。

; Sun, 08 Oct 2023 02:22:01 +0800 Terence Davies, award-winning filmmaker, dies at 77https://www.theguardian.com/film/2023/oct/07/terence-davies-award-winning-filmmaker-dies-at-77
;;2023-10-07T17:39:00Z;
;
;;特伦斯·戴维斯，2022 年在他的埃塞克斯小屋拍摄
;

;特伦斯·戴维斯，电影 -这位经常被评论家誉为英国最伟大制作人的导演去世，享年 77 岁。

;

;这位出生于利物浦的导演，也许以其对工人阶级家庭生活的半自传式研究而闻名;;遥远的声音，仍然由皮特·波斯尔思韦特 (Pete Postlethwaite) 主演的《生活》(Lives) 在他生病时正在制作一个新项目，仅在两年前发布;;Benediction;;，由杰克·劳登主演，饰演战争角色诗人西格弗里德·沙逊。

;

;戴维斯因其低电压、敏感的方式呈现现实生活的戏剧而受到赞赏，让演员能够记录情感的微小变化。评论他 2015 年电影的标志性抒情风格和主题 ;;日落之歌;;改编自刘易斯·格拉西克·吉本 (Lewis Grassic Gibbon) 的 1930 年代苏格兰三部曲的第一部，影评人乔纳森·罗姆尼 (Jonathan Romney) 指出，这部电影与他早期的利物浦电影基调相呼应1988 年的家庭剧。“凄凉与狂喜交织在一起，形成了交响乐般的效果，”罗姆尼写道。这两部电影都以暴力的父亲形象为特色，这是戴维斯七岁时去世的父亲的影子。

;

;2000 年，戴维斯改编了伊迪丝·沃顿的 ;;《欢乐屋》;;，获得英国电影和电视艺术学院 (Bafta) 提名，并在时隔八年之后与;;时间与城市;;，一部关于利物浦的档案纪录片。他将特伦斯·拉蒂根 (Terence Rattigan) 的激烈舞台剧改编成电影，;;《深海》;;，下一部是 2011 年上映的，2016 年，他在 ;;安静的激情;;。

;

;两周前戴维斯当他接受一部新短片《消逝的时间》（《埃塞克斯的三分钟视角》）采访时，解释了他的导演技巧背后的一些想法。他告诉;根特电影节;网站，“在我看来，大多数演员花费了太多的时间‘表演’。没有人愿意看到有人在银幕上表演。演员应该感受，而不是表演，否则就不真实。”

;

;他说，答案在于选对演员：“我亲自见到每个人，本能地知道他们是否适合这个角色。 。我可以直接看出他的“表演”，然后礼貌地说“不，谢谢”。 ……“表演”很少发生在片场，但如果真的发生，通常都是有原因的——这是漫长的一天，他们很焦虑，或者你知道片场外发生了什么事。你必须去感受这些事情。一个温和的建议，让我们忘记他们已经准备好的东西，“只是摸着石头过河”，通常会让我们到达目的地，然后他们会做出一些我从未想过的奇妙事情，这就是魔力。”

;

;A戴维斯承认，今年早些时候宣布的制作一部名为《邮局女孩》的电影的计划已经失败，但他对他正在编写的新剧本抱有希望，以讲述一个以《邮局女孩》为背景的故事。牙买加。

;

;去年春天，戴维斯在埃塞克斯的小屋里发表讲话 ;告诉《卫报》的 Ryan Gilbey;，他也看重电影中的笑话。 “幽默是如此迷人，”他说。 “尤其是当它掩盖了悲剧时。”

;

;他解释说，他从未与男性或女性伴侣住在一起，或者真的想这样做：“我不太擅长生活，”他说。 “因为人与人之间的互动，无法正确解释事物。”

;

;吉尔贝表示，他实际上可能对事物理解得太透彻了。 “我现在无法忍受的一件事就是气氛，”戴维斯回忆起他父亲在童年时期长期恶毒的沉默，说道。 “我可以走进一个满是人的房间，我可以告诉你是谁吵架了。我总是说：如果我让你不高兴了，那就出来吧。如果你冷落我，我立刻就会看到;他;坐在客厅的角落里，我又回到了七岁的孩子。”

;

; Sat, 07 Oct 2023 22:22:01 +0800 Off-duty US air force officer saves fallen climber on Yosemite’s Half Domehttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/oct/07/air-force-officer-rescues-climber-yosemite-half-dome
;;2023-10-07T12:00:11Z;
;
;;The 8,842ft high summit of the Half Dome at Yosemite national park.
;

;An off-duty US air force flight instructor braved strong winds, hail and slippery conditions to rescue a fellow climber who had fallen about 80ft (24.4 meters) down a slippery slope at Yosemite national park this past Labor Day weekend, according to ;the military branch;.

;

;Joshua Haveman's valiant actions not only earned him a hero's praise from his air force colleagues – but they also prevented another hiking tragedy from occurring after the last few months have seen multiple hikers lose their lives amid a range of perilous conditions.

;

;Haveman, a captain by rank, was making an attempt to summit Yosemite's ;Half Dome; on 2 September 2023 when the emergency he helped resolve unfolded.

; ;

;The Half Dome summit stands at 8,842ft (2.7 kilometers). And Haveman was within the final 400ft (122 meters) when he noticed a fellow climber fall amid the dreary, chilly conditions.

;

;Haveman watched as the climber plummeted about 80ft and landed on a ledge that measured only about 6ft (1.8 meters) by 1.5ft (0.4 meters). That space was the only thing separating the climber from another fall of at least 500ft (152 meters).

;

;The flight instructor at California's Travis air force base wasted no time trying to reach the fallen climber, though parts of that section of the Half Dome require hikers to negotiate difficult granite surfaces. Haveman ventured beyond permanent cable barriers that are placed to give climbers added safety and leverage in hopes of approaching the distressed climber, which he managed to do while bringing a first aid kit along.

;

;“Other climbers were concerned for my safety, but the guy was just … there screaming in pain,” Haveman told officials at the Travis base, about a four-hour drive from the Half Dome. “So I left the cable area and climbed on the ledge.”

;

;It soon became apparent to Haveman why the fallen hiker was screaming: his legs were mangled.

; ;

;“You could see that his legs were not naturally oriented at all,” Haveman said.

;

;Haveman had gathered sticks on the way to the injured climber. He fashioned them into makeshift splints and then used them to secure the hiker above and below his lower leg break.

;

;Haveman also wrapped the hiker's injured ankle in a bandage and used his own jacket to cover him, shielding him from the harsh elements and staving off apparent shock.

;

;From there, Haveman arranged for a call to be placed to the park ranger's station. His clear communication about his and the wounded climber's position in the park helped emergency responders find them, air force officials said.

;

;A park ranger specializing in search and rescue operations soon arrived. The ranger and Haveman helped the injured hiker descend a cable ladder before another emergency responder arrived with a full medical bag, including higher-quality splints.

;

;Meanwhile, the weather improved, and more climbers arrived to help improvise a pulley system which helped the wounded hiker complete the descent. A helicopter crew eventually arrived to fly the hiker out of the area and to the emergency care he needed at that point.

; ;

;Haveman credited his ability to respond effectively to a life-or-death situation to his prior climbing experience as well as his training in a type of first aid known as tactical combat casualty care. He said he was also glad he kept his guard up given how badly the conditions had deteriorated late in his attempt to summit the Half Dome.

;

;“I knew people were going to be in trouble as soon as I topped the hill because it was cold and windy and people were getting desperate trying to come down,” Haveman said.

;

;Not every close call on such excursions has a happy outcome. On 23 September, a 61-year-old woman hiking along the Blue Ridge parkway in North Carolina ;died after plunging about 150ft; off a waterfall overlook.

;

;A woman died in August after falling off a mountain during a hike in ;Wyoming's Grand Teton national park;. A porter died in July after falling during an ascent of K2, the world's second-highest mountain.

;

;In June, ;a teenage boy died; after falling ill as he hiked in dangerously high temperatures of 119F (48.3C) during a visit to south-west Texas's Big Bend national park. Then the boy's stepfather was killed after he crashed his car during a desperate search for help.

;

;Another teenage boy in August ;survived; falling 100ft from a ledge at the Grand Canyon. Having received hospital treatment for his injuries, the teen said in an interview that he realized he had been “inches away from death”.

; Sat, 07 Oct 2023 20:22:01 +0800 Biden accused of betrayal of Khashoggi over push to deepen Saudi tieshttps://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/oct/07/biden-saudi-arabia-mohammed-bin-salman-jamal-khashoggi

;

;Joe Biden is facing accusations of betraying a pre-election promise to re-evaluate ties with Saudi Arabia over the murder of Jamal Khashoggi in favour of pursuing a rapprochement with the kingdom aimed at repelling a challenge from China to US primacy in the Middle East.

;

;The charge, from human rights campaigners and some Democrats, follows the fifth anniversary of Khashoggi's death at the hands of Saudi regime agents and comes amid mounting criticism of a proposed new defence treaty between Washington and Riyadh that could result in Saudi Arabia granting official recognition to Israel.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Five years after killing a journalist in cold blood, Saudi Arabia is stronger than ever | Mohamad Bazzi;

;
;

;Biden took office initially intending to downplay the traditional US role in the Middle East, a policy consistent with holding Saudi Arabia at arm's length following the outcry that greeted Khashoggi's murder.

;

;But the president has since performed a volte-face by saying on a visit to the region that the US would “remain an active, engaged partner” and adding: “We will not walk away and leave a vacuum to be filled by China, Russia, or Iran.”

;

;The Biden administration's initially cool relations towards Saudi Arabia began to warm, according to analysts, after Russia's invasion of Ukraine in February last year triggered international sanctions, forcing western countries to seek urgent alternatives to Russian energy supplies.

;

;Biden visited Riyadh, the Saudi capital, in July last year, where he held talks with Mohammed bin Salman, the crown prince. The pair were photographed in a fist-bump greeting.

;

;The president said afterwards he told the crown prince that he held him personally responsible for Khashoggi's murder, adding that Prince Mohammed denied culpability.

;

;The administration later ruled that the crown prince enjoyed head-of-state immunity from any decision by an American court on the murder of Khashoggi, who had been living in exile in the US before his death.

;

;Vali Nasr, professor of international affairs and Middle East studies at Johns Hopkins, said the accusations that the administration had abandoned its position on Khashoggi were justified. But he said “realpolitik” had driven Washington to deepen ties after China brokered a restoration of long-severed diplomatic relations between Saudi Arabia and Iran last March, in what was seen as a major geostrategic coup for Beijing.

;

;“The US wants to drive a wedge between China and Saudi Arabia,” Nasr said. “The increased involvement of China in the Gulf has been a concern to Washington, and when the Chinese were able to resolve an intractable problem between the Saudis and Iran, it told Washington that China's involvement in the region was more than just commercial.”

;

;Now Prince Mohammed, Saudi Arabia's prime minister and de facto ruler, is haggling for a pact – which could include security guarantees and US technology to develop a nuclear energy programme – in return for establishing full diplomatic ties with Israel, a prized goal of the Biden administration.

;

;The Saudi leader is also pressing for Israeli concessions to the Palestinians, a potential stumbling block for the hard-right coalition government of Israel's prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu, which has pledged to build more settlements in the occupied West Bank on land claimed by the Palestinians as part of a future state.

;

;Khashoggi, a Saudi dissident and Washington Post columnist, was tortured and then strangled after being ambushed by a state hit squad on 2 October 2018 after entering the Saudi Arabian consulate in Istanbul, where he had gone to obtain paperwork for his forthcoming marriage. His body was dismembered, reportedly using a bone saw, and later disposed of.

;

;A subsequent CIA investigation concluded that the murder had been committed on the orders of Prince Mohammed.

;

;Activists say the latest diplomatic overtures sully Khashoggi's memory and violate Biden's campaign promise that his death would “not be in vain”.

;

;“It is a betrayal not just of Jamal Khashoggi and the millions of people of Saudi Arabia whose lives Prince Mohammed has destroyed, but also of the promises President Biden made to the American people to end support for this autocratic, sociopathic government,” said Sarah Leigh Whitson, executive director of Dawn, a pro-democracy group founded by Khashoggi months before his murder.

;

;“Now he is going a step further by committing America to unprecedented security guarantees that would obligate American servicemen and women to uphold the rule of this dictator. This is something that not even the Trump administration did.

;

;“It's a sad reflection of a misplaced priority that the US must maintain hegemony and pre-eminence in the Middle East at all costs, which is pathetic because we now live in a multi-polar world.”

; ;

;In October 2020, marking the second anniversary of Khashoggi's murder, Biden pledged that his administration would “reassess our relationship with the kingdom … and make sure America does not check its values at the door to sell arms or buy oil”.

;

;“America's commitment to democratic values and human rights will be a priority, even with our closest security partners,” he said.

;

;Now those same values are being invoked by members of Biden's own party after 20 Democratic senators signed a letter to him expressing concerns about the proposed defence treaty.

;

;“A high degree of proof would be required to show that a binding defence treaty with Saudi Arabia – an authoritarian regime which regularly undermines US interests in the region, has a deeply concerning human rights record and has pursued an aggressive and reckless foreign policy agenda – aligns with US interests,” the letter says.

;

;The letter also demands that Israel does not annex any part of the West Bank and stop the construction of settlements on the territory to meet Biden's stated aim of “preserving the option of a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict”.

;

;Nasr said: “The stakes for the US are much bigger than the human rights record of one leader, because it's trying to play a much bigger strategic game against China while trying to resolve a big conflict between the Arabs and Israel. It's not going to hold those issues subservient to its position on Jamal Khashoggi.”

;

;Jon Alterman, director of the Middle East programme at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, said additional factors prompted the US démarche, including internal reforms which he said had led to progress on the rights and status of women.

;

;“Saudi Arabia is a country with enormous deployable wealth. It's a country of robust intelligence capabilities, if you are looking at counter-terrorism,” he said. “It's important to global energy markets. It's an asset in many other ways.

;

;“You can have a US policy in the Middle East that tries to suppress Saudi Arabia, but everything becomes a lot harder to do and a lot less successful if you cannot get a Saudi Arabian buy-in.”

;

;Referring to the murder of Khashoggi, who he said had been a friend, Alterman added: “I don't think Saudi Arabia can be defined purely through the prism of that crime.
